definition: Wu Zetian (624-705), Tang empress, reigned 690-705
martial/military
surname Wu
(conjunction used to express contrast with a previous clause) but/then/standard/norm/principle/to imitate/to follow/classifier for written items
day/sky/heaven

sentences.english: Empress Wu's remarks aroused a high degree of vigilance Di Gong.
sentences.chinese: 武則天的話引起了狄公高度的警惕。

sentences.english: The reason why the Empress Wu did not kill him, because he established the snake spirit organization.
sentences.chinese: 而武則天之所以沒殺他，是因爲他建立了蛇靈組織。

sentences.english: This change happens when Wu Zetian's power rises to a historical height.
sentences.chinese: 這個變化是在武則天走向權力顛峯的背景下出現的。

sentences.english: Famous poet Li Bai, once regarded her as one of the seven sages in Tang Dynasty.
sentences.chinese: 著名詩人李白，就把武則天列爲唐朝“七聖”之一。

sentences.english: The decrees for pardon that are delivered during Wu Zetian's rule begin to experience great changes.
sentences.chinese: 在武則天時期所頒佈的赦文中開始出現了重大的變化。

sentences.english: But for the Empress, and the actress, the imprisonments were only temporary setbacks.
sentences.chinese: 但對於武則天和劉曉慶而言，監禁只是暫時的困難。

sentences.english: Believe that the strength of their own be able to better my Wu.
sentences.chinese: 相信的自己的實力能夠把武則天演好。

sentences.english: Empress Wu was also one of the most powerful champions of Buddhism in China.
sentences.chinese: 武則天也是中國歷史上最強勢的佛教擁護者。

sentences.english: Empress Wu of the Tang dynasty was the only female Emperor of China .
sentences.chinese: 武則天唐代是中國唯一的女皇帝。

sentences.english: Wu came from the land of the special care and favor.
sentences.chinese: 武則天從太平降世就對她傾瀉了特別的關心和溺愛。

definition: Di Renjie (607-700), Tang dynasty politician, prime minister under Wu Zetian, subsequently hero of legends/master sleuth Judge Dee, aka Chinese Sherlock Holmes, in novel Three murder cases solved by Judge Dee 狄公案[Di2 gong1 an4] translated by Dutch sinologist R.H. van Gulik 高羅珮|高罗佩[Gao1 Luo2 pei4]
harem/chambers of imperial concubines
senior concubine/imperial consort
palace maid/CL:個|个[ge4],名[ming2],位[wei4]
foster mother/adoptive mother
Puyi, personal name of the last Qing emperor (reigned as child 1909-1911), the subject of Bertolucci's biopic The Last Emperor

Diaochan (-192), one of the four legendary beauties 四大美女[si4 da4 mei3 nu:3], in fiction a famous beauty at the break-up of Han dynasty, given as concubine to usurping warlord Dong Zhuo 董卓[Dong3 Zhuo2] to ensure his overthrow by fighting hero Lü Bu 呂布|吕布[Lu:3 Bu4]
Pan Jinlian (name lit. Golden Lotus), heroine of Ming dynasty vernacular novel Jinpingmei or the Golden Lotus 金瓶梅
Wei State (407-225 BC), one of the Seven Hero States of the Warring States 戰國七雄|战国七雄/Wei State or Cao Wei 曹魏 (220-265), the most powerful of the Three Kingdoms
Liu Bei (161-223), warlord at the end of the Han dynasty and founder of the Han kingdom of Shu 蜀漢|蜀汉 (c. 200-263), later the Shu Han dynasty
imperial concubine or palace maid/imperial secretary (old)
king/CL:個|个[ge4]
Liu Chan 劉禪|刘禅 (207-271), son of Liu Bei, reigned as Shu Han emperor 233-263
to confer a title upon sb/to dub/to crown/to invest with rank or title
Chow Yun-Fat (1955-), Hong Kong TV and film star
to act/to play a part
